chunks.contextual_summary: This chunk presents Berkshire Hathaway's per-share book value growth compared to the S&P 500 over multiple five-year periods from 1965 to 2010. It highlights periods of strong relative performance and market cycles, illustrating Berkshire's long-term outperformance despite recent market stagnation. The detailed table supports understanding of Berkshire's historical competitive advantage.

chunks.start_anchor:
Intrinsic Value – Today and Tomorrow
Though Berkshire’s intrinsic value cannot be precisely calculated, two of its three key pillars can be
measured. Charlie and I rely heavily on these measurements when we make our own estimates of Berkshire’s
value.
chunks.end_anchor:
2000-2010 6.6%
Though our compounded annual increase in per-share investments was a healthy 19.9% over the
40-year period, our rate of increase has slowed sharply as we have focused on using funds to buy operating
businesses.
chunks.contextual_summary: This chunk explains Berkshire's intrinsic value components, focusing on investments and insurance float as measurable pillars. It presents tables showing the growth of per-share investments and non-insurance earnings over decades, highlighting a strategic shift toward acquiring operating businesses. The data illustrates Berkshire's evolving capital allocation approach and its impact on value creation.

chunks.start_anchor:
For the forty years, our compounded annual gain in pre-tax, non-insurance earnings per share is 21.0%.
During the same period, Berkshire’s stock price increased at a rate of 22.1% annually. Over time, you can expect
our stock price to move in rough tandem with Berkshire’s investments and earnings. Market price and intrinsic
value often follow very different paths – sometimes for extended periods – but eventually they meet.
chunks.contextual_summary: This chunk discusses the relationship between Berkshire's intrinsic value, stock price, and the importance of management's capital deployment skills. Buffett emphasizes that intrinsic value depends not only on current assets but also on future reinvestment efficacy. He highlights Berkshire's advantages in management quality, capital allocation flexibility, and culture as key to sustaining growth despite size challenges.
chunks.prev_context: This chunk explains Berkshire's intrinsic value components, focusing on investments and insurance float as measurable pillars.

chunks.principle_statement: The value of a business depends critically on the quality of capital allocation and management’s ability to reinvest earnings effectively.

chunks.start_anchor:
Partially offsetting our anchor of size are several important advantages we have. First, we possess a
cadre of truly skilled managers who have an unusual commitment to their own operations and to Berkshire.
Many of our CEOs are independently wealthy and work only because they love what they do. They are
volunteers, not mercenaries. Because no one can offer them a job they would enjoy more, they can’t be lured
away.
chunks.contextual_summary: This chunk outlines Berkshire’s management philosophy, emphasizing the independence, dedication, and owner-like mindset of its CEOs. Buffett highlights the decentralized management style, minimal interference, and trust placed in managers, which fosters a strong culture and operational excellence. The capital allocation freedom and culture are presented as key competitive advantages.

chunks.principle_statement: A decentralized management approach with trusted, owner-minded CEOs fosters operational excellence and long-term success.

chunks.start_anchor:
When I took control of Berkshire in 1965, I didn’t exploit this advantage. Berkshire was then only in
textiles, where it had in the previous decade lost significant money. The dumbest thing I could have done was to
pursue “opportunities” to improve and expand the existing textile operation – so for years that’s exactly what I
did. And then, in a final burst of brilliance, I went out and bought another textile company. Aaaaaaargh!
chunks.end_anchor: we are then able to compare any one opportunity against a host of others.
chunks.contextual_summary: This chunk recounts Buffett’s early missteps in capital allocation, particularly his misguided investments in textile businesses after acquiring Berkshire. He reflects on learning from these mistakes and shifting focus to insurance and other industries. The story illustrates the importance of capital allocation discipline and the advantage of comparing diverse investment opportunities.
